The product liability doctrine was developed in the first years of the modern era for products of commercial importance. A contract for manufacturing, marketing and selling of a product, as well as in the case of a hazardous product (such as a nuclear weapon or explosive device that could produce a serious injury to its intended or perceived consumers ), had to consider the possibility of claims against such a product in order to determine the appropriate liability for injuries resulting from its manufacture.
